unnormalised: ## Ditching the CDs: My Adventures in Music Streaming (and Yours?)
normalised: ## Ditching the C D s: My Adventures in Music Streaming (and Yours?)

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Remember those days of painstakingly ripping CDs onto our computers? Or queuing up at Planet M in Mumbai, hoping they had the latest Bollywood soundtrack? Those days feel like ancient history now, thanks to music streaming.
normalised: Hey everyone! Remember those days of painstakingly ripping C D s onto our computers? Or queuing up at Planet M in Mumbai, hoping they had the latest Bollywood soundtrack? Those days feel like ancient history now, thanks to music streaming.

unnormalised: Seriously, who isn't hooked on streaming these days? Whether you're on Spotify, Apple Music, or Gaana, the convenience is undeniable. I mean, think about it: millions of songs at your fingertips, ready to soundtrack your morning chai or that long commute from Delhi to Gurgaon (feels like a lifetime, am I right?).
normalised: Seriously, who isn't hooked on streaming these days? Whether you're on Spotify, Apple Music, or Gaana, the convenience is undeniable. I mean, think about it: millions of songs at your fingertips, ready to soundtrack your morning chai or that long commute from Delhi to Gurgaon (feels like a lifetime, am I right?).

unnormalised: I used to be a staunch CD loyalist. I even had a whole rack dedicated to Lata Mangeshkar and Kishore Kumar! But the lure of instant access was too strong. Plus, my cousin, Priya, who's studying engineering at IIT Madras, convinced me. She said, "C'mon, Auntie! You can finally listen to those obscure Carnatic albums you were always complaining about not finding!" She had a point.

unnormalised: And the playlists! Oh, the playlists. You can find everything from "Bollywood Party Anthems" to "Relaxing Ragas for Studying" to, my personal favorite, "90s Indie Rock Throwbacks." The algorithms are pretty good too, suggesting artists I never would have discovered otherwise. Recently, I discovered a fantastic Rajasthani folk band thanks to a Spotify recommendation!

unnormalised: Of course, there are downsides. Data costs can be a pain, especially when travelling to remote areas. And sometimes, the curated playlists feel a little…generic. But overall, the pros outweigh the cons. Plus, supporting the artists (even if it's just a tiny fraction of a rupee per stream) feels better than pirating music, right?
